reviewText: Just like with all the other Baby Einstein DVDs, this truly blessed my son. I remember when we got this for him when it came out. He really took a liking to it, and he started repeating phrases and acting out the story in the video. It really impressed his speech therapist (my son is hearing impaired). She said he really used what hearing he had to hear and understand it, because you can't read the lips of animation.It blessed me to see him trying to say more words by memorizing such an educational video. He even sings the songs! He LOVES rocket, and he spins around and signs the word "airplane" with both hands as he runs around.This series really reinforces and sparks imaginative play and helped my son a lot! I highly recommend this video, as well as the others. Even though my son hasn't watched this one in a while, because he's hooked on the "Mission Celebration" one, this is still a favorite of his.
Title: N/A

reviewText: We never got into the Baby Einstein videos, but I love this DVD because it focuses on education that is largely ignored in other series.  Rather than the typical letters/reading or numbers/counting type lessons, this movie (and the series) blend music, science, geography, and culture together.  In addition to that, the kids love it.  I think this was the best Christmas present that my kids received this year.Bonus features are also good, especially the Disneypedia.  I would've been estatic if that section had been expanded to include more places (i.e. one related to the art, for example).

Title: N/A

reviewText: My daughter, has watched Baby Einstein videos since she was 6 months old, she has always LOVED them.  Now that she has turned three her grandmother bought her this new DVD since it says it's for toddlers, etc.  However, my daughter will not watch it now after seeing it only once!  There is a scene with thunder, lightning, and a very violent storm that blows a little caterpillar into the water.  She was very worried & anxious about water, storms, etc. after seeing this dvd.  I'm hoping that any new episodes will take the whole "toddler appropriate" thing seriously.  I think this dvd is more for 5 years plus.  For now we're sticking to the good old Baby Einstein line.  One other note, the music is great, the main song from the dvd is from Beethoven's 9th Symphony (can't remember exact name of it), which is one of the most recognizable classical songs, and one of my favorite's that I like to listen to.  Since my daughter became afraid of the dvd, when she hears that song she now thinks of the STORM from the show which is sad because the music is happy & uplifting and shouldn't remind her of something scary.
summary: Small children may be afraid of the storm

reviewText: No need for me to repeat what others have said.  If your babies love the Baby Einstein series and have outgrown it then they will love this.  My 2 y.o. daughter loooooved the Einstein videos and now she loves this.  She adores the show and screams when she can't watch it.  It is so wonderful how they introduce a composer and artist of the day.  This is truly an educational show in a more genuine way than many of the others that claim to be.  Unfortunately this is the one and only Little Einsteins available for sale.  My daughter has watched it already 20 times at least.  The tv show comes on twice a day here but I think we've seen all of them.  I was dissappointed they did not have any Little Einstein toys or videos out for Christmas as it is what my daughter wants the most!

reviewText: The Little Einsteins series is wonderful for my children.  They are able to learn about other places, cultures, forms of art, and get to listen to gorgeous music while they do so.Simple theory is taught.  Counting as well as pattern recognition are among the skills learned.They are fun for adults to watch too.  Some of the story lines become repetitive, but the children are learning the concepts almost completely.

reviewText: How can you not love a program that has your child learning compositions from famous composers and learning to appreciate art at age four?  This is a WONDERFUL DVD and will go down in my book as a Disney classic.  The nicest thing about this new series is that the kids are just on a mission each episode; exploring a new piece of music, teaching about a new geographical area, learing about a new instument, etc.  This is unlike other kid's programming where the kids are sitting around trying to think of ways to be nice to each other and share and have good manners, etc. It's tough to take as a parent in the same room with the TV.  I really like this new addition to the Disney Family.

reviewText: If you wonder how much this video can stick with toddlers, here's a tip: our son calls our car "ROCKET". After loving Baby Einsteins when he was little, he has loved Little Einsteins since they came out. But it's not just him: I admit I have a weakness for the series and I can sit down through the episodes without a problem, being as they are, focused on music, the arts and travel through the world. I don't just enjoy them, I recommend them. Watching these guys fly on their adventures is an activity I can see many parents doing alongside their kids.

reviewText: If you are not familiar with the Little Einstein series, you really should take a look.  Not like alot of Disney's other banal TV productions, this show really has merits.I mean how can you not like a show that has your children yelling staccato and legato, adagio and allegro. And knowing what these terms mean!Children are taught that music has `layers' and that the musical `themes' can be representative of a particular character or action.  For example, a crescendo may help the sun rise, or a wave get bigger.In addition, children are introduced to fine art, architecture, and landmarks from around the world.  Examples (not necessarily from this video) include works from Gaughan, Monet, the Seattle Space Needle, the Great Sphynx, Antartica, the Great Wall of China....Five Stars.  A wonderful introduction to fine art and classical music that 'sticks' with young children.  The stories combine fun, kid adventures and elements of music and art in a way that seems very natural and memorable.Plot for this video:For their first mission, Annie, Leo, Quincy, June and Rocket help a little caterpillar become a beautiful Monarch butterfly.Music:  Beethoven's 9th Symphony.Artist:  Van Gogh, Monet, HokusaiReal-world destinations:  New York City, Oklahoma, and Texas.
summary: Little Einstein's--  They've got my kids yelling 'Alegro'

reviewText: Ok, I know the words to all the songs, I'll admit it. My 1 yr old loves this movie!!!  I work from home so I need something to occupy him for a little while.  He "sings" along with it and even yells "blast-off" when Rocket takes off. (well ok, he yells bla bla, but he's only one)  It's a fun movie and a life saver.  They have to help the caterpillar turn into a butterfly and then they have to help him migrate to Mexico.  Now whenever he sees a butterfly he "sings" the butterfly song.  great movie!
summary: We're going on a trip in our favorite rocket ship, zooming through the skies...

reviewText: The DVD quality is low, the sound kept fading in and out, which wasn't a total deal breaker for us but did get slightly annoying as the video played. My daughter was never a huge Baby Einstein fan, but I thought we'd try one more video before ruling it out. The content of the video is not very entertaining. My daughter lost interest in it within the first few minutes of it starting. The music is good, which did hold her attention when the songs were playing. Beyond that, she barely paid attention to the screen the rest of the time. If you and your kids like Baby Einstein, give the video a try. If you're on the fence about Baby Einstein, I'd advise you to buy a different video. Word World, Super Simple Learning, among others, are big hits in our household.
